author: jason.carver
content: <@!403636673914863626> maybe the `TRIN_DB_PATH` environment variable is set to a folder that your user doesn't have access to write to? Or maybe its parent directory is missing?

author: jason.carver
content: Yeah, this seems promising! One interesting effect is that a node becomes perpetually responsible for any given account, so as the state root changes, you'll still ask the same node for updates to that account. Although the address hashes are randomly distributed (kind of, more on that in a sec), the *interest* in addresses is probably not. Most users will hit the ENS registry at some point, for example. This is similar to the problem of everyone being interested in the peer that's storing the state root, but at least that interest is for a limited time period. Once a node launches, it would perpetually be responsible for the same accounts (roughly). So there could be some incentive to re-roll the private key if you start hosting a "too-hot" spot of the state.

author: jason.carver
content: Anyone can do some work to tilt the balance away from random distribution (just run a bunch of hashes on random addresses), but of course there is a cost to create those addresses, if you want to unbalance the trie. (Although it's a one-time cost that's borne indefinitely)

author: jason.carver
content: So we would need to do some analysis on how big a slice of state a client might choose, and look at the cost of making that state 2x or 10x bigger than the others. (ie~ how much gas do you have to spend to create a bunch of addresses with the same first byte. Assuming the clients tend to split the state space into 1/256 chunks (which seems a reasonable approximation: it would mean storing less than 1G), how much gas would it take to store `1/25.6 * (total number of addresses)` in the state. This ignores storage, but the principle is the same, for when we go a bit deeper on the analysis.

author: samwilsn
content:
I would argue that `D` doesn't hold unless you can guarantee that a node in your own routing table has the data you want (which I don't think you can?)

I think kademlia gives you `O(log(n))` at best for lookups.

author: samwilsn
content: Read this as "kicked off the project" initially and was quite shocked.

author: jason.carver
content: Yeah, I agree with you, that the statement as written is not correct. My eyes auto-corrected to `0(1)` *content* lookups, each one of which takes `O(log(n))` network lookups

author: samwilsn
content: I guess you could argue that `n` is bounded, so you have `O(1)` but that screams shenanigans.

author: jason.carver
content: Then in the naive network, a single account lookup takes `O(log(n))` content lookups, which takes `O(log^2(n))` network lookups. (I'm still using very loose definitions, and these should probably be different n's)

author: samwilsn
content: Wait... I don't even think its `O(log(n))`, it's `”®(log(n))` if my memory about `”®` serves.
